intro: Acacia langlassei, commonly known as the Langlasse's acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, often multi-branched stems and bipinnate leaves that are reduced to small, scale-like structures in mature plants. The plant produces yellow flowers in compact spherical or cylindrical inflorescences, which are typically visited by various pollinators. Acacia langlassei is adapted to survive in harsh, dry conditions with deep root systems and a slow growth rate. It is also known for its ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen, contributing to soil fertility in its native habitat.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia langlassei is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa, particularly Namibia and Angola. It thrives in sandy soils and is commonly found in savanna and shrubland ecosystems. This plant is well adapted to hot, dry climates and can tolerate low rainfall conditions. It plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species. Its distribution is largely restricted to the specific environmental conditions found in these regions.
